title: Ike's grandson: Today's media and polarization 'would have confused him'
content:
When Republican presidential candidate Dwight D. Eisenhower made a series of television commercials during his 1952 campaign , the two major networks at the time initially refused to air them , considering the spots undignified .
So what would Ike have thought of today 's presidential campaigning , with a constant barrage of attacks and counterattacks on broadcast and cable television channels and the Internet ?
`` The media environment and political polarization would have confused him , '' said his grandson , David Eisenhower , a noted historian and director of the Annenberg School for Communication 's Institute for Public Service at the University of Pennsylvania .
Eisenhower , 67 , spoke about his grandfather 's role as World War II general and 1950s president , American politics and world issues at a dinner and lecture Wednesday night in Doylestown sponsored by the Penn Club of Bucks County . More than 50 University of Pennsylvania alumni attended the event at Bobby Simone 's restaurant and bar .
`` We 've experienced a great deal of dysfunction in American politics over the years , '' said Eisenhower , currently working on a book about Ike 's presidency from 1953 to 1961 . His previous books include `` Eisenhower at War , 1943-1945 '' ( published in 1986 ) and `` Going Home To Glory : A Memoir of Life with Dwight David Eisenhower , 1961-1969 '' ( published in 2010 ) .
`` How can our country be in such good shape and our politics in such bad shape ? '' asked Eisenhower , who has been married since 1968 to Julie Nixon Eisenhower , daughter of Richard M. Nixon , the Republican president from 1969 to 1974 as well as Ike 's vice president .
The current crop of presidential candidates `` are fighting a war '' among themselves , according to Eisenhower , for whom the presidential retreat in Maryland was named `` Camp David . ''
He said Donald Trump has stressed the theme of `` America first '' to become the Republican front-runner .
`` There 's a feeling the international economy is not working well for America . Trump is getting a response on that issue , '' said Eisenhower , who teaches an undergraduate course on politics that involves students attending the Republican and Democratic conventions .
While Eisenhower said he does not expect Trump to be the Republican nominee , the billionaire will have an impact on the presidential campaign .
Ever since Republican Ronald Reagan 's presidency in the 1980s , presidents have acted as `` boosters for America , '' Eisenhower said . As a result , issues take a back seat in presidential campaigns .
During his first term , President Eisenhower used his wartime experience as supreme Allied commander in Europe to reach an understanding with the Soviet Union and avoid nuclear war . Once that goal was achieved , the second term was less successful , according to his grandson .
`` The presidency is a real meritocracy . It 's a mission-oriented job , '' Eisenhower said . Presidential candidates seek a mandate to carry out their mission .
He said he is optimistic about the country 's future , whoever is elected president next year .
`` I think our country is on an upward trend , despite our differences , '' Eisenhower said .
